definition:
If a plane curve $\gamma$ has a continuing infinitely far from the
origin $O$, then $\gamma$ may have an [*asymptote*]{}: The direct line
$l$ is an asymptote of $\gamma$, if
$$\lim_{d(P, \,O) \to \infty}d(P, \,l) = 0,$$ where $d(P, \,O)$ means
the of the point $P$ of the from the origin and $d(P, \,l)$ the of $P$
from the line $l$.

**Examples**: The hyperbola $\frac{x^2}{a^2}-\frac{y^2}{b^2} = 1$ has
the asymptotes $y = \pm\frac{b}{a}x$; the curve $y = \frac{\sin x}{x}$
the asymptote $y = 0$.
